Reminder that wanting to be objectified in one area of life does mean you want to be objectified in others A woman happy being sexualized in the confines of her content is under no obligation to want that same sexualization in public or elsewhere

Males have jobs sometimes that must mean they want to be exploited for their labor for free
Also  some of us are not okay with being objectified at all If you look into it even some of the women doing it might not be truly okay with it
Thats like saying bar staff are ok with being asaulted because they chose that job
See also women who want to go top free in exactly the same context that men are allowed to MUST want these dudes to make gross sksualized comments at them or worse try to cop a feel

sexualized and objectified are two very different things and its sad how many people think of them as the same I am fine with being seen as sexy and sexually appealing in context Im never okay with being seen as an object for someones desires
Sex workers are still human and should never be objectified even if you are paying them for content

Creole in Belize  is broken English Colonized by the British
Belizean Creole also Louisiana Creole I heard was different too

Mi e taki Sranan Tongo I speak Sranan Tongo a creole language spoken in Suriname  I recently commented in on of your post that Ive proudly had that on my CV for years now as one of the many languages Ive come to speak and understand Its the unofficial second language of the Surinamese people Apart from that I also speak two other Maroon Creole languages Saamaka and Ndyuka tongo  as Im a decendant of Maroons from both tribes This is not uncommon in Suriname
Im going to try and work linguistic imperialism into my work conversations this week
Oh yes I love this as a Louisiana creole living in Charleston surrounded by Gullah  EducationIsImportant
Not me just learning the meaning of Patwa  My heart Let me just go ahead and start calling it Jamaican Creole cause my heart cannot today

I speak papiamentu which is a combination of portuguese spanish english and also dutch With also french influence Mi gustame gusta  i like Kompronde comprendre  to understand Bondia Bom dia  good morning or good day Hope this helps

Im half Haitian first generation Canadian on my dads sideand I never learnedwas never taught Haitian creole I one time lemented to my Jamaican born yet extremely Eurocentric boss  opening up to her because I had few folks in my life at the time from the Caribbean so I stupidly thought she would understand that I wished that I had learned to speak creole I still to this day regret opening up to her she was so white washed She looked at me blankly and said why on earth would you want to speak creole you should learn French Shocked and hurt by her response I simply replied it would be nice to be able to speak to my family in our own language Although I unfortunately only speak English Im elated that Creole in all its shapes and forms are finally slowly slowly being recognized as proper language
Love it Im here for the sociolinguistic facts

Guadeloupean creol Ki jan aw  Bèl mèsi pou wouchaj ou ka ménè pa pèpla Sé on min ka lavé lot  In English  how you doing  Big thanks for your work and for the knowledge you gave for our people Its a hand who wash the other  its an expression to say that we are all connected and our actions lead to the success of all
Theres also Martiniquan creole
I learn something new from every post Thank you
Teach TEACHER

WOW So Manglish Malaysian English  Singlish Singaporean English is a form of Englishbased creole Theres a restaurant in London called Roti King and on the wall is this big sentence Wei macha you want to makan here or tapau In this sentence is a mix of Chinese English Tamil and Malay and for a native it makes complete sense  My mind is blown

Self defense class should be mandatory in all elementary and high schools

Why arent we fixing the male problem My daughter myself and her friend were followed all around Tj maxx once I walked up and yelled at the oldest male What else can we do Its 2024 and we as women have to constantly worry about our safety
I was 19 the first time despite being jailbait from a young age It was horrific what he said to me I almost myself Instead I pushed him as hard as I could and ran Im 65 and the memory still scares me
I was 12 walking to the corner store for a snack in the summer 2 min walk This older boyman would constantly say stuff like when youre 16 youre gonna be mine when I walked past him
Be loud be rude stay safe

Mi e taki Sranan Tongo I speak Sranan Tongo a creole language spoken in Suriname  I recently commented in on of your post that Ive proudly had that on my CV for years now as one of the many languages Ive come to speak and understand Its the unofficial second language of the Surinamese people Apart from that I also speak two other Maroon Creole languages Saamaka and Ndyuka tongo  as Im a decendant of Maroons from both tribes This is not uncommon in Suriname

Oh yes I love this as a Louisiana creole living in Charleston surrounded by Gullah  EducationIsImportant
Not me just learning the meaning of Patwa  My heart Let me just go ahead and start calling it Jamaican Creole cause my heart cannot today

I speak papiamentu which is a combination of portuguese spanish english and also dutch With also french influence Mi gustame gusta  i like Kompronde comprendre  to understand Bondia Bom dia  good morning or good day Hope this helps

Im half Haitian first generation Canadian on my dads sideand I never learnedwas never taught Haitian creole I one time lemented to my Jamaican born yet extremely Eurocentric boss  opening up to her because I had few folks in my life at the time from the Caribbean so I stupidly thought she would understand that I wished that I had learned to speak creole I still to this day regret opening up to her she was so white washed She looked at me blankly and said why on earth would you want to speak creole you should learn French Shocked and hurt by her response I simply replied it would be nice to be able to speak to my family in our own language Although I unfortunately only speak English Im elated that Creole in all its shapes and forms are finally slowly slowly being recognized as proper language
Love it Im here for the sociolinguistic facts

Guadeloupean creol Ki jan aw  Bèl mèsi pou wouchaj ou ka ménè pa pèpla Sé on min ka lavé lot  In English  how you doing  Big thanks for your work and for the knowledge you gave for our people Its a hand who wash the other  its an expression to say that we are all connected and our actions lead to the success of all
Theres also Martiniquan creole

WOW So Manglish Malaysian English  Singlish Singaporean English is a form of Englishbased creole Theres a restaurant in London called Roti King and on the wall is this big sentence Wei macha you want to makan here or tapau In this sentence is a mix of Chinese English Tamil and Malay and for a native it makes complete sense  My mind is blown
